DOC.HEAD: Jury Recommends 16 Years for Man Convicted in Church Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: The man who caused the deaths of 27 people on a church bus in the nation's worst drunken-driving accident was taken to jail after a jury recommended a 16-year prison sentence. But the relatives of some of his victims said the jury, which rejected murder charges to find him guilty of manslaughter, was too lenient. They noted Larry Mahoney still has a family to celebrate Christmas with. ``We're going to spend it in a cemetery with a headstone,'' Bill Nichols, said after a sentencing hearing Friday, clasping hands with his wife, Madeline. The couple's only child, 17-year-old William Joseph Nichols Jr., was among the 24 youths and three adults killed by smoke inhalation and flames in a fire that swept through a former school bus after Mahoney's pickup struck it on Interstate 71, five miles south of Carrollton. Mahoney was drunk and driving on the wrong side of the highway when the crash occurred May 14, 1988. Mahoney, 36, who had been free on bond prior to his conviction, was led in handcuffs out of the Carroll County Courthouse Friday and taken to the local jail after Circuit Judge Charles Satterwhite discontinued his bail. Mahoney was convicted on Thursday of 27 counts each of second-degree manslaughter and first-degree wanton endangerment, 12 of first-degree assault, 14 of second-degree wanton endangerment and one of drunken driving. The jury on Friday recommended sentences totaling 611 years, but opted to have them run concurrently. That effectively gave Mahoney 16 years of a possible 20-year sentence for assault, the most serious offense. He would be eligible for parole consideration in eight years under Kentucky law. Satterwhite is to sentence Mahoney February 23. The judge can give Mahoney a lighter sentence, but cannot exceed the jury's recommendation. ``If you ask me if I'm disappointed, yeah, I'm disappointed,'' said Assistant Attorney General Paul Richwalsky, who prosecuted Mahoney on 27 murder counts. ``I thought all of the carnage ... was worth more than eight years in prison.'' The jury's recommendation shocked Karen Morgan, president of Students Against Drunk Driving at Radcliff's North Hardin High School. ``It's going to be hard going back to my school and ... telling them that this man only got a minimum of eight years,'' said Miss Morgan, whose 13-year-old brother, Phillip, was among those killed. ``What kind of example do you set for them?'' Defense attorneys William Summers and Russell Baldani said they were pleased with the verdicts and sentencing recommendation, but will appeal the convictions. ``What is (Mahoney's) life worth?'' Summers said. ``Will it bring somebody back? Will it make them feel better?'' At his sentencing hearing, Mahoney told the jury he intended to lecture schoolchildren on the evils of drinking and driving.
